Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Steps Toward a Physical Understanding of the Star Formation Law
Award.AbstractNarration:
The funding of this proposal, titled "CAREER: Steps Toward a Physical Understanding of the Star Formation Law", will allow Dr. Bolato to study the relation between star formation and gas over a range of galactic environments with the ultimate goal of determining the physical mechanisms that drive star formation. The combination of new facilities like Spitzer, EVLA, ALMA, and JWST and the recent advances in modeling techniques make it possible for the first time to make detailed comparisons between observations and model predictions. From low-mass galaxies and the outer disks of spirals to the environs of starburst galaxies, this proposal will study the atomic and molecular gas involved with the process of star formation in a wide range of environments.

The broader impacts of the proposal range from the mentoring of undergrad students to the creation of a public lecture series in Spanish for the U. Maryland observatory program. One graduate will be supported for the duration of the grant. Dr. Bolato will give a series of public lectures in both English and Spanish as part of the University of Maryland observatory program. In addition to the education related broader impacts the PI will also develop an "Astronomy Workshop Toolbox" in English and Spanish for use in high-school astronomy classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How did the universe we see today come to be?  Galaxies evolve through cosmic time by accreting gas through mergers of directly from the "cosmic web", and evolve by processing this gas and converting it to stars. The goal of this project is to increase our understanding of the processes regulating the conversion of gas into stars in galaxies, which play a key role in their evolution. The relation between gas and star formation activity in galaxies is known as "the star formation law". A better understanding the star formation law and its driving mechanisms can only come from a concerted effort to study gas and starformation on several scales in a range of galaxy environments.  This project produced calibrations of star formation rate indicators in the far-infrared, and measurements of the relation between gas and star formation across different spatial scales and galactic environments, studying the impact of molecular gas properties and metallicity on the rate of producting of stars.

An example is shown in the attached picture,  displaying the results of our ALMA observations of one of the nearest "starburst" galaxies, NGC253, which is experiencing a burst of star formation in its nuclear regions. Our measurements show that the giant molecular clouds in this environment are extraordinarily dense and appear to be self-gravitating (rather than bound by external pressure). The very large densities result in accelerated time-scales for star formation, which may explain the extraordinary activity in the center of this object.
